Description: Airbus agreed to pay $527 million to the United States to resolve foreign bribery charges and alleged violations of the Arms Export Control Act and the International Traffic in Arms Regulations. This was part of a $3.9 billion settlement that also involved authorities in the United Kingdom and France. The U.S. portion includes $5 million credited toward a $10 million penalty imposed by the State Department Directorate of Defense Trade Controls (see separate entry).

Airbus SE settled allegations that it violated the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) in connection with the provision of false statements on authorization requests; the failure to provide accurate and complete reporting on political contributions, commissions, or fees that it paid, or offered or agreed to pay, in connection with sales; the failure to maintain records involving ITAR-controlled transactions; and the unauthorized re-export and retransfer of defense articles. At around the same time, Airbus entered into a $527 million settlement with the Justice Department, which included a $5 million credit toward the DDTC penalty (see separate entry).
Agency: State Department Directorate of Defense Trade Controls

Description: Airbus U.S. Space & Defense Inc., formerly known as Airbus Defense and Space Inc., agreed to pay to the United States $1,043,475 to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by billing impermissible fees in contracts with a number of federal agencies.
